summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the proposed protective order in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The government opposes two specific requests from the defense: (1) to publicly name and identify victims who have spoken publicly about Epstein or Maxwell, and (2) to impose restrictions on the government's use of its own investigative materials. The government argues for protecting victim privacy under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking modifications to the protective order to allow public naming of victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased co-conspirator; the crimes discussed relate to his and Maxwell's alleged sexual abuse of victims.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this government letter is addressed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney who signed and submitted this letter on behalf of the government.

persons.name: Corley
persons.context: Referenced in a cited case (United States v. Corley) as an example where victim identities were protected.

persons.name: Kelly
persons.context: Referenced in a cited case (United States v. Kelly) as an example where witness identities were protected.

connections.description: The document repeatedly links Maxwell and Epstein as alleged perpetrators of sexual abuse against the same victims.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is prosecuting the case against Maxwell.

events.title: Defense Submission of Proposed Protective Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel submitted a letter and proposed protective order to the court, which this government letter is responding to.

events.title: Protective Order Negotiations
events.description: The government and defense counsel conferred several times via telephone and email regarding the terms of a protective order.

events.title: Epstein Prosecution and Suicide
events.description: Reference to the prior criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein (19 Cr. 490) and its dismissal following his suicide.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government strongly opposes the defense's request to publicly name victims who have ever spoken about Epstein or Maxwell in any public forum, calling it 'extraordinarily broad, unnecessary, and inappropriate.'

The government's proposed protective order would allow the defense to reference victim identities in private conversations with potential witnesses and in sealed filings, but not in public statements.

The government argues victim privacy is protected under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (18 U.S.C. ยง 3771), which includes the right to be protected from the accused and to have dignity and privacy respected.
The defense also sought to restrict the government's use of its own investigative documents when sharing them with witnesses, a request the government calls 'unprecedented' and 'without legal basis.'

The document reveals a strategic conflict where the defense seeks to publicly name victims, potentially to discourage cooperation, while the government seeks to shield them from public scrutiny and harassment.
